After [Mitch McGary](/wiki/Mitch_McGary "Mitch McGary") attempts a [finger
roll](/wiki/Finger_roll "Finger roll") [layup](/wiki/Layup "Layup") late in
the first half of the [2012–13 Big Ten Conference men's basketball
season](/wiki/2012%E2%80%9313_Big_Ten_Conference_men%27s_basketball_season
"2012–13 Big Ten Conference men's basketball season") opener on January 3
(left), the [Michigan
Wolverines](/wiki/2012%E2%80%9313_Michigan_Wolverines_men%27s_basketball_team
"2012–13 Michigan Wolverines men's basketball team") and [Northwestern
Wildcats](/wiki/2012%E2%80%9313_Northwestern_Wildcats_men%27s_basketball_team
"2012–13 Northwestern Wildcats men's basketball team") anticipate (center) and
pursue (right) the [rebound](/wiki/Rebound_\(basketball\) "Rebound
\(basketball\)"). The possession demonstrates the end-of-half intricacies of
the [National Collegiate Athletic
Association](/wiki/National_Collegiate_Athletic_Association "National
Collegiate Athletic Association")'s former 35-second shot clock (red
[LED](/wiki/LED "LED")) when possession changes and the game clock (white LED;
note the decimal point) is below 35 seconds.

A **shot clock** is used in some sports to quicken the pace of the game. It is
normally associated with [basketball](/wiki/Basketball "Basketball"), but is
also used in [snooker](/wiki/Snooker "Snooker"),
[pro](/wiki/Major_League_Lacrosse "Major League Lacrosse")
[lacrosse](/wiki/Lacrosse "Lacrosse"), [water polo](/wiki/Water_polo "Water
polo"), [korfball](/wiki/Korfball "Korfball"), and [ten-pin
bowling](/wiki/Ten-pin_bowling "Ten-pin bowling"). It is analogous with the
[play clock](/wiki/Play_clock "Play clock") used in
[American](/wiki/American_football "American football") and [Canadian
football](/wiki/Canadian_football "Canadian football").

In basketball, the shot clock is a [timer](/wiki/Timer "Timer") designed to
increase the game's pace and scoring.[1] The offensive team must attempt to
get the ball into the basket by the ball leaving the player's hand before the
shot clock expires, and the shot must either touch the
[rim](/wiki/Breakaway_rim "Breakaway rim") or enter the basket. If the
offensive team fails to register a field goal attempt within the time limit,
they are assessed a violation resulting in a
[turnover](/wiki/Turnover_\(basketball\) "Turnover \(basketball\)") to their
opponents; if the ball hits or enters the rim after the clock expires, it is
not a violation so long as it left the player's hand _before_ expiration. The
maximum time limit of the shot clock varies by level of play and league: The
[National Basketball Association](/wiki/National_Basketball_Association
"National Basketball Association") has had a 24-second limit since first
introducing the clock in the 1950s; and college basketball for both men and
women has a 30-second limit. The
[WNBA](/wiki/Women%27s_National_Basketball_Association "Women's National
Basketball Association") had a 30-second clock originally; since 2006 the
limit is 24 seconds, just like in the NBA.

## History[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Shot_clock&action=edit&section=1 "Edit
section: History")]

### Background[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Shot_clock&action=edit&section=2
"Edit section: Background")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2a/GeorgeMikan.jpg/220px-
GeorgeMikan.jpg)](/wiki/File:GeorgeMikan.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:GeorgeMikan.jpg "Enlarge")

Stall tactics to limit big man [George Mikan](/wiki/George_Mikan "George
Mikan") (#99) led to the shot clock's creation by the NBA.

The NBA (National Basketball Association) had problems attracting fans (and
positive media coverage) before the shot clock's inception.[2] This was due to
teams [running out the clock](/wiki/Running_out_the_clock "Running out the
clock") once they were leading in a game; without the shot clock, teams passed
the ball nearly endlessly without penalty. If one team chose to stall, the
other team (especially if behind) would often commit fouls to get the ball
back following the free throw. Very low-scoring games with many fouls were
common, which bored fans. The most extreme case occurred on November 22, 1950,
when the [Fort Wayne Pistons](/wiki/Fort_Wayne_Pistons "Fort Wayne Pistons")
defeated the [Minneapolis Lakers](/wiki/Minneapolis_Lakers "Minneapolis
Lakers") by a record-low score of 19–18, including 3–1 in the fourth
quarter.[3] The Pistons held the ball for minutes at a time without shooting
(they attempted 13 shots for the game) in order to limit the impact of the
Lakers' dominant [George Mikan](/wiki/George_Mikan "George Mikan"). The
Pistons' performance led the _[St. Paul Dispatch](/wiki/St._Paul_Dispatch "St.
Paul Dispatch")_ to write "[The Pistons] gave pro basketball a great black
eye."[4] NBA President [Maurice Podoloff](/wiki/Maurice_Podoloff "Maurice
Podoloff") said, "In our game, with the number of stars we have, we of
necessity run up big scores."[5] A few weeks after the Pistons/Lakers game,
the [Rochester Royals](/wiki/Rochester_Royals "Rochester Royals") and
[Indianapolis Olympians](/wiki/Indianapolis_Olympians "Indianapolis
Olympians") played a six-overtime game with only one shot in each overtime -
in each overtime period, the team who had the ball first held the ball for the
entirety of the period before attempting a last-second shot. The NBA tried
several rule changes in the early 1950s to speed up the game and reduce fouls
before eventually adopting the shot clock.

### Creation[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Shot_clock&action=edit&section=3 "Edit
section: Creation")]

The shot clock first came to use in 1954 in [Syracuse, New
York](/wiki/Syracuse,_New_York "Syracuse, New York"), where [Syracuse
Nationals](/wiki/Syracuse_Nationals "Syracuse Nationals") (now the
Philadelphia 76ers) owner [Danny Biasone](/wiki/Daniel_Biasone "Daniel
Biasone") and general manager [Leo Ferris](/wiki/Leo_Ferris "Leo Ferris")
experimented using a 24-second version during a scrimmage game.[6] According
to Biasone, "I looked at the box scores from the games I enjoyed, games where
they didn't screw around and stall. I noticed each team took about 60 shots.
That meant 120 shots per game. So I took 2,880 seconds (48 minutes) and
divided that by 120 shots. The result was 24 seconds per shot."[3][7] Biasone
and Ferris then convinced the NBA to adopt it for the [1954–55
season](/wiki/1954%E2%80%9355_NBA_season "1954–55 NBA season"), a season in
which the Nationals won the [NBA Championship](/wiki/1955_NBA_Finals "1955 NBA
Finals").

Syracuse Nationals General Manager [Leo Ferris](/wiki/Leo_Ferris "Leo Ferris")
has emerged in the discussion as one of those involved in the creation and
development of the shot clock. Along with Danny Biasone and Emil Barboni, a
scout for the Nats, Leo Ferris was a key figure in developing the 24-second
clock.[8] Jack Andrews, longtime basketball writer for The Syracuse Post-
Standard, often recalled how Ferris would sit at Danny Biasone's Eastwood
bowling alley, scribbling potential shot clock formulas onto a napkin.[9]
Ferris, who loved mathematics, ended up dividing the number of seconds in a
48-minute game (2,880) by the average number of shots taken in a game (120) to
get to the 24-second time limit per possession.[10] While he and Biasone often
share in the credit for the shot clock, it was Ferris who was singled out by
business manager Bob Sexton at the 1954 team banquet for pushing the shot
clock rule.

### Use and
reaction[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Shot_clock&action=edit&section=4 "Edit
section: Use and reaction")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f2/Syracuse_Shot_Clock_Monument.jpg/300px-
Syracuse_Shot_Clock_Monument.jpg)](/wiki/File:Syracuse_Shot_Clock_Monument.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Syracuse_Shot_Clock_Monument.jpg "Enlarge")

The Shot Clock Monument in [Syracuse, New York](/wiki/Syracuse,_New_York
"Syracuse, New York").

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c0/Syracuse_Shot_Clock_Monument_Close-
Up.jpg/300px-Syracuse_Shot_Clock_Monument_Close-
Up.jpg)](/wiki/File:Syracuse_Shot_Clock_Monument_Close-Up.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Syracuse_Shot_Clock_Monument_Close-Up.jpg "Enlarge")

Close-up of Syracuse's Shot Clock Monument.

When it was first introduced by the NBA, the 24-second shot clock made players
so nervous that it hardly came into play, as players were taking fewer than 20
seconds to shoot. According to [Syracuse](/wiki/Syracuse_Nationals "Syracuse
Nationals") star [Dolph Schayes](/wiki/Dolph_Schayes "Dolph Schayes"), "We
thought we had to take quick shots – a pass and a shot was it – maybe 8–10
seconds... But as the game went on, we saw the inherent genius in Danny's 24
seconds – you could work the ball around [the offensive zone] for a good
shot."[7]

The shot clock, together with some rule changes concerning fouls,
revolutionized NBA basketball. In the last pre-clock season
[(1953–54)](/wiki/1953%E2%80%9354_NBA_season "1953–54 NBA season"), teams
averaged 79 points per game; in the first year with the clock
[(1954–55)](/wiki/1954%E2%80%9355_NBA_season "1954–55 NBA season"), the
average was 93 points,[3] which went up to 107 points by its fourth year in
use [(1957–58)](/wiki/1957%E2%80%9358_NBA_season "1957–58 NBA season").[11]
The advent of the shot clock (and the resulting increase in scoring) coincided
with an increase in attendance, which increased 40% within a few years to an
average of 4,800 per game.[12]

The shot clock received near-universal praise for its role in improving the
style of play in the NBA. Coach and referee [Charley
Eckman](/wiki/Charley_Eckman "Charley Eckman") said, "Danny Biasone saved the
NBA with the 24-second rule."[13] Boston Celtic all-star [Bob
Cousy](/wiki/Bob_Cousy "Bob Cousy") said, "Before the new rule, the last
quarter could be deadly. The team in front would hold the ball indefinitely,
and the only way you could get it was by fouling somebody. In the meantime,
nobody dared take a shot and the whole game slowed up. With the clock, we have
constant action. I think it saved the NBA at that time. It allowed the game to
breathe and progress."[14] League president [Maurice
Podoloff](/wiki/Maurice_Podoloff "Maurice Podoloff") called the adoption of
the shot clock "the most important event in the NBA."[3] The league itself
states, "Biasone's invention rescue[d] the league."[13]

### Adoption by other
leagues[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Shot_clock&action=edit&section=5 "Edit
section: Adoption by other leagues")]

Two later pro leagues that rivaled the NBA adopted a modified version of the
shot clock. The [American Basketball
League](/wiki/American_Basketball_League_\(1961%E2%80%931963\) "American
Basketball League \(1961–1963\)") used a 30-second shot clock for its two
years in existence (1961–1963). The [American Basketball
Association](/wiki/American_Basketball_Association "American Basketball
Association") also adopted a 30-second clock when it launched in 1967–68,
switching to the NBA's 24-second length for its final season
[(1975–76)](/wiki/1975%E2%80%9376_ABA_season "1975–76 ABA season").

In the 1969–70 season, women's collegiate basketball (at the time sanctioned
by the [Commission on Intercollegiate Athletics for
Women](/wiki/Commission_on_Intercollegiate_Athletics_for_Women "Commission on
Intercollegiate Athletics for Women")) used a 30-second shot clock on an
experimental basis, officially adopting it for the 1970–71 season.[15] Unlike
the women's side, there was initial resistance to the implementation of a shot
clock for men's [NCAA](/wiki/National_Collegiate_Athletic_Association
"National Collegiate Athletic Association") basketball, due to fears that
smaller colleges would be unable to compete with powerhouses in a running
game. However, after extreme results like an 11–6
[Tennessee](/wiki/Tennessee_Volunteers_basketball "Tennessee Volunteers
basketball") win over [Temple](/wiki/Temple_Owls_men%27s_basketball "Temple
Owls men's basketball") in 1973, support for a men's shot clock began to
build.[16] The NCAA introduced a 45-second shot clock for the men's game in
the 1985–86 season, reducing it to 35 seconds in the 1993–94 season[17] and 30
seconds in the 2015–16 season.[18] The NAIA also reduced the shot clock to 30
seconds for men's basketball starting in 2015–16.[19]

From its inception in [1975](/wiki/1975_PBA_season "1975 PBA season"), the
[Philippine Basketball Association](/wiki/Philippine_Basketball_Association
"Philippine Basketball Association") adopted a 25-second shot clock. This was
because the shot clocks then installed at the league's main venues, the
[Araneta Coliseum](/wiki/Araneta_Coliseum "Araneta Coliseum") and [Rizal
Memorial Coliseum](/wiki/Rizal_Memorial_Coliseum "Rizal Memorial Coliseum")
(the latter no longer used by the league), could only be set at 5-second
intervals. The league later adopted a 24-second clock starting from the [1995
season](/wiki/1995_PBA_season "1995 PBA season"). The [Metropolitan Basketball
Association](/wiki/Metropolitan_Basketball_Association "Metropolitan
Basketball Association") in the Philippines used the 23-second clock from its
maiden season in 1998. In Filipino college basketball, the [NCAA Basketball
Championship (Philippines)](/wiki/NCAA_Basketball_Championship_\(Philippines\)
"NCAA Basketball Championship \(Philippines\)") and the [UAAP Basketball
Championship](/wiki/UAAP_Basketball_Championship "UAAP Basketball
Championship") adopted a 30-second clock; they switched to 24 seconds starting
with the 2001–02 season, the first season to start after the FIBA rule change
in 2001.

## Operation[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Shot_clock&action=edit&section=6 "Edit
section: Operation")]

In the NBA (since 1954), [Women's National Basketball
Association](/wiki/Women%27s_National_Basketball_Association "Women's National
Basketball Association") (since 2006), and [FIBA](/wiki/FIBA "FIBA") play
(since 2000; 30-second from 1956 to 2000), the shot clock counts down 24
seconds, thus often being called the "24-second clock." If a shot is attempted
and hits or enters the rim, or if the defensive team gains possession via a
[rebound](/wiki/Rebound_\(basketball\) "Rebound \(basketball\)"),
[steal](/wiki/Steal_\(basketball\) "Steal \(basketball\)"), or out-of-bounds
play, the shot clock resets. Failure by the offense to attempt a shot that
hits the rim within the prescribed time results in a "shot clock violation"
and a [loss of possession](/wiki/Turnover_\(basketball\) "Turnover
\(basketball\)") to the other team. Three signals indicate when the shot clock
expires—a shot clock signal, illuminated lights on the shot clock (NBA, FIBA,
Euroleague, and many venues using an NBA-style transparent shot clock), and in
the NBA and FIBA play (starting in July 2018), a yellow [LED](/wiki/LED "LED")
light strip on the backboard. In the [2011–12 NBA
season](/wiki/2011%E2%80%9312_NBA_season "2011–12 NBA season") and [2014–15
Euroleague](/wiki/2014%E2%80%9315_Euroleague "2014–15 Euroleague"), the last
five seconds of the shot clock were modified to include tenths of a second,
allowing offensive players to see precisely how much time they have to shoot
and officials to determine any last-second shots easily. The rule has been
adopted by FIBA starting in 2018.[20] In the [2016-17 NBA
season](/wiki/2016-17_NBA_season "2016-17 NBA season"), a new 'official
timekeeper' deal for the NBA with Swiss watch manufacturer
[Tissot](/wiki/Tissot "Tissot") introduced a new united official game
clock/shot clock system, putting both timing systems under the same system for
the first time.[21] Tissot also became official timekeeper for the WNBA in the
2017 season.

Furthermore, the shot clock is not reset on a foul in the frontcourt. Rule
changes in the NBA since 1998, and in FIBA after 2010 state the shot clock
will be reset only if 13 seconds or fewer are on the shot clock, after which
it is reset to 14 seconds.

The NBA and Euroleague have different rules on the shot clock reset on [jump
balls](/wiki/Jump_ball "Jump ball"); while both leagues have jump balls
retained by the offense are reset to 14 seconds (if 13 seconds or fewer are on
the shot clock), in the NBA, if the defense causes the jump ball, the shot
clock is not reset if the offense keeps control of the ball unless under 5.0
seconds of time remain, where it is reset to 5.0 seconds.

Also in FIBA/WNBA play, if the offence retains control of a ball following a
rebound, the shot clock is reset to 14 seconds.

Since the 2015–16 season, all American college basketball uses a 30-second
shot clock, while Canadian university basketball uses a 24-second clock. The
American women's game has used a 30-second clock since the 1970s, but the
men's game did not adopt a shot clock until 1985. The men's limit was
originally 45 seconds, and was shortened to 35 seconds in 1993 before going to
30 seconds in 2015. The [National Federation of State High School
Associations](/wiki/National_Federation_of_State_High_School_Associations
"National Federation of State High School Associations") (NFHS), which sets
rules for high school basketball in the U.S., does not mandate the use of a
shot clock, instead leaving the choice to use a clock and its duration up to
each individual state association. Proposals to adopt a national shot clock
for high school basketball have been voted down by the NFHS as recently as
2011.[22] Currently, eight U.S. states require the use of a shot clock of
30/35 seconds in high school competition: California, Maryland, Massachusetts,
New York, North Dakota, Rhode Island, South Dakota, and Washington.[22]

## Similar rules in
basketball[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Shot_clock&action=edit&section=7 "Edit
section: Similar rules in basketball")]

The shot clock and its enforcement is used in concert with the
[rule](/wiki/10-second_basketball_rule "10-second basketball rule") that
requires an offensive team to advance the ball across half-court and into the
offensive zone (or front court) within a referee's count (this rule was first
introduced in 1933, predating the shot clock by over 2 decades). In men's
college basketball, the offense must advance the ball to the front court
within 10 seconds, the same length used by [FIBA](/wiki/FIBA "FIBA") and the
[NBA](/wiki/National_Basketball_Association "National Basketball Association")
until they adopted an 8-second limit in 2000 and 2001, respectively. Failure
by the offense to advance the ball to the front court within the time limit
results in a [turnover](/wiki/Turnover_\(basketball\) "Turnover
\(basketball\)") to the other team.

Generally, the 10-second (or 8-second) count is independent from the shot
clock's operation; in fact, a referee may count the 8 or 10 seconds through a
visible motion of his hand or arm. Women's college basketball introduced the
10-second limit in 2013–2014, and provided that officials will not count the
ten seconds but "will use the shot clock to determine if a 10-second violation
has occurred." As a general reference, it refers to the shot clock reaching 15
(FIBA/[W]NBA; because the NBA shot clock registers tenths in the final five
seconds, the violation occurs once the clock registers 15.9 seconds on the
console, which is posted as 15 on the clock) or 20 (college) before a
violation can be called.[25]

qa.question: what happens when you get a shot clock violation

nq_3040_21.Query Analysis: The query asks about the consequence of a shot clock violation in basketball.
nq_3040_21.Answer Analysis: The answer indicates that a shot clock violation results in a turnover to the opposing team.
nq_3040_21.Document Content Analysis: The document discusses the rules and history of the shot clock in basketball, including the time limits for advancing the ball and the consequences of failing to do so, such as turnovers. It also mentions different shot clock rules in various basketball leagues and contexts.

nq_3040_21.Key Information Matching: The document explains that failure to advance the ball within the shot clock limit results in a turnover, directly addressing the consequence of a shot clock violation.
nq_3040_21.Can the Document Answer the Query: Yes, the document directly states that a violation results in a turnover, which answers the query.

nq_3040_21.Explanation: The document is directly relevant to the query as it provides a clear answer to what happens during a shot clock violation and offers additional context about shot clock rules, making it highly useful for understanding the query's topic.
